issue.title: Added tests and fix for generic procedure calling in return type
issue.body: Added tests and fix for generic procedure calling in return type from [gitlab/lfortran](https://gitlab.com/lfortran/lfortran/-/merge_requests/1754/diffs?commit_id=4b33cd67e2462e532c7608afc00933ba95019807).


One ASR has `(FunctionCall 33 len_string 2 len [((Var 33 string))] (Integer 4 []) () ())` while the other one has `(FunctionCall 33 len_string () [((Var 33 string))] (Integer 4 []) () ())`, in other words, the `original_name` is empty in one. Some kind of random behavior seems to be happening, which signals a bug, that is only triggered on @Pranavchiku's computer. We should find it and fix it.

Ok, on Pranav's computer it is using the intrinsic len I think, while at the CI it is using the use defined len function. It happens in this code:
```fortran
    function compute_lps_use1(string) result(l)
        type(string_type), intent(in) :: string
        integer :: l
        print *, char(string)
    end function compute_lps_use1
```
Which translates to:
```
(FunctionCall 
                                            33 char@char_string 
                                            6 char 
                                            [((Var 33 string))] 
                                            (Character 1 -3 (FunctionCall 
                                                33 len_string 
                                                2 len 
                                                [((Var 33 string))] 
                                                (Integer 4 []) 
                                                () 
                                                ()
                                            ) []) 
                                            () 
                                            ()
                                        )
```

The actual bug I think comes from the definition of this function:
```fortran
pure function char_string(string) result(character_string)
    type(string_type), intent(in) :: string
    character(len=len(string)) :: character_string

end function char_string
```
Which should have the following ASR definition for the return variable:
```
                                            character_string:
                                                (Variable 
                                                    5 
                                                    character_string 
                                                    ReturnVar 
                                                    () 
                                                    () 
                                                    Default 
                                                    (Character 1 -3 (FunctionCall 
                                                        2 len_string 
                                                        2 len 
                                                        [((Var 5 string))] 
                                                        (Integer 4 []) 
                                                        () 
                                                        ()
                                                    ) []) 
                                                    Source 
                                                    Public 
                                                    Required 
                                                    .false.
                                                ), 
```

And it does in both results. But in one case the copying of this does not set the `original_name` correctly.
